Here are some photos that scare me the most: Cameraman killed by race car engineAt the U.S. national Hot Rod Races in Indianapolis, cameraman Joe Rooks was filming the race when one of the cars crashed near him and its blower flew down the track and struck him in the back, killing him. Captain Nguyễn Văn Lém’s executionA war correspondent caught the exact moment the bullet from a pistol pierced the skull of a north Vietnamese officer during the Vietnam war. The expression on his face is one that’s in unbelievable pain, and I find it one that’s hard to forget. Royalist mobs lynched and killed many students like him during the Thammasat U massacre.  Strange fruitThis photo depicts two young African American men hanging from a tree after being lynched by a mob. This photo haunts me. Seeing the two lifeless bodies dangling, and the all-white crowd smiling and pointing like what they’ve just participated in is a good thing makes me sick. This was taken in the U.S. South in the 30s. The two men were accused of having raped and robbed a white woman, a story that sounds very much like the case of Tom Robinson from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird. This photo also inspired a song by Billie Holiday, that is quite haunting once you realize the real meaning. You can find it below the photo.  Attempted murderThis photo was taken in Moscow, and shows the moment a victim had a filleting pike stuck into his gut by an attacker. The look of disbelief on the victim’s face saddens me. If you look in the background you’ll see that the accomplice of the murderer is keeping another man occupied so that he ignores the attack. What also baffles me is that this happened in broad daylight, with a photographer able to see it. This photograph was also very well timed to be able to catch the exact moment the attack occurred.  StalingradThis is a photo of dead German soldiers from the battle of Stalingrad. You can see the pile extends all the way to the back of the photo, and for all we know even farther. The death toll was one of the highest in WW2, and seeing these frozen and lifeless bodies stacked like garbage is quite disturbing and scary.  Sunken manThis is Odjegba Okene. He was a cook on a South African Transport ship when it faced rough waters and sunk. Some divers went to the bottom of the ocean where the ship had touched down, intending to recover dead bodies. While going through the ship, they found him in an air pocket where he’d been stuck for 3 days, chest deep in sea water and darkness. Although it has a happy ending and he was rescued, this pictures always creeps me out because it shows me an exasperated man, so happy to know he’s surviving, but also shows how terrible his ordeal must have been. Not knowing why you're alive, if you’re going to get out alive, plus having sea water blanketing most of your body is a very terrifying scenario. The video of his rescue is very interesting as well, and can be found on Youtube.  Accident on the fire escapeThis is a photo that captures the moment that a young mother and her young child fell to the ground when a fire escape collapsed during an apartment fire. A firefighter had tried to rescue them but as he stepped on to the escape, it broke under their weight. The child actually survived because his mother’s body broke his fall. This photo is chilling to me because the woman in this photo died a few seconds after this was taken.  Jewish test subjectThis is a photo from Dachau concentration camp during the Second World War. It shows a Jewish prisoner during one of the many experiments that Nazi doctors performed to test the effectiveness of various military prototypes. In this picture, they’re testing the effect of oxygen deprivation on the human body, because Luftwaffe pilots could face this issue. The Jewish prisoner has passed out from deprivation, or could possibly even be dead. Another common test was to immerse Jews in cold sea water to see how long they could survive. It’s unbelievable and sickening that anyone could treat a human this way.

As they were suffocating to death, the prisoners of Auschwitz left those scratches on the walls of the gas chambers. They signed with their fingernails on the death of humanity. Between 1942 and 1944, hundreds of thousands of Jews were brought from all across Europe to Auschwitz - the Nazi’s most infamous extermination camp. Located in Southern Poland, Auschwitz was the closest to hell on Earth. It was built and then expanded as part of the Nazi’s plan for the complete annihilation of the Jewish people in Europe - the plan they named “The Final Solution to the Jewish Question”. Here, killing was industrialized. And murder had a new definition.  Upon arrival, those who were deemed unfit for work would be immediately sent to the crematorium. Pregnant women, children, the elderly, and the mentally ill had no right to breathe anymore…in the eyes of the Nazis.  “Men to the left. Women to the right”. SS officers’ greeting for the new arrivals to the death camp. In his emotional and heart-wrenching book “Night”, Elie Wiesel recalls the day on which he arrived in Auschwitz. That morning, Elie’s family was torn apart. His innocence was murdered after witnessing what he’d thought to be beyond impossible. He watched his mother and sister being taken away from him…forever. He was only 15 years old. His sister was 7. Standing there, helpless, he gazed at the top of the building to which they were being taken. Flames were coming out of the chimneys. Little did he know at the time that those flames would later feed on the flesh of his mother and sister. Or perhaps, he didn’t want to believe it.  “Not far from us, flames were leaping up from a ditch, gigantic flames. They were burning something. A lorry drew up at the pit and delivered its load-little children. Babies! Yes, I saw it -saw it with my own eyes . . . those children in the flames.” Elie Wiesel. Documented in these disturbing images are the moments of separation. On the right is the path to the gas chambers. On the left, the road to enslavement, hunger, and torture under the mercy of hope for a long-awaited liberation.  “Never shall I forget that night, the first night in camp, which has turned my life into one long night, seven times cursed and seven times sealed. Never shall I forget that smoke. Never shall I forget the little faces of the children, whose bodies I saw turned into wreaths of smoke beneath a silent blue sky” Elie Wiesel. Refusing to believe what he just saw, fearful that his mother and little sister would face the same destiny, Elie tells his father “I do not believe that they could burn people in our age, humanity will never tolerate it. ...” To which his father replied, in a broken voice…  “Humanity? Humanity is not concerned with us. Today anything is allowed. Anything is possible, even these crematories. . . .” Frightened that he, too, might be thrown into the flames, Elie says…  “Father, if that is so, I don’t want to wait here. I’m going to run to the electric wire. That would be better than slow agony in the flames.” His father doesn’t utter a word. Those moments of horror would be engraved in Elie’s memory. The first days in Auschwitz changed him forever.  “Never shall I forget those flames which consumed my faith forever. Never shall I forget that nocturnal silence which deprived me, for all eternity, of the desire to live. Never shall I forget those moments which murdered my God and my soul and turned my dreams to dust. Never shall I forget these things, even if I am condemned to live as long as God Himself. Never”. To prevent mass hysteria, before entering the gas chambers, inmates were told that they’d be getting into the shower. Some of them were even given a soap and a towel. They then stripped off their clothes while the executers stripped off their humanity. Only when the gas was released did the victims realize that death was imminent. They had no other choice but to scratch the walls with their fingernails in a desperate attempt to survive. Perhaps they can make it back to the outside - back to the world that let them down. But it was all in vain. Twenty minutes later, the pain was gone.  “I pinched my face. Was I still alive? Was I awake? I could not believe it. How could it be possible for them to burn people, children, and for the world to keep silent? No, none of this could be true. It was a nightmare. ... Soon I should wake with a start, my heart pounding, and find myself back in the bedroom of my childhood, among my books. ..” More than 1 million people were killed inside Auschwitz in the span of four years. As many as 15,000 were burned every single day. As one historian puts it: “You have to stop being human in order to believe that they were burning people alive in the middle of the twentieth century”. The atrocities committed inside the walls of Auschwitz will always be a stain on humanity. r/AskHistorians - Are the nail marks made on the walls Auschwitz gas chambers real or not? The quick and dirty version is that a young girl drown on the island and, sometime after, a doll rose to the surface. The owner of the island, Don Julian Santana Barrera, presumed the doll had belonged to the little girl. He hung it in a tree as a show of respect for the young girl. The gesture was to no avail, however, as her spirit continued to haunt him. In response, he hung even more dolls to appease her. Barrera passed away in 2001, and the island has become a popular tourist attraction, where visitors come to hang even more dolls. Post-mortem photography was a trend in Victorian England to preserve the image of a family when a loved one died.  Two parents pictured with their deceased daughter. Post-mortem photography became common in Victorian England when the rise of early photography coincided with the short life spans of individuals. They were also known as "memento mori" photos, meaning "remember you must die." As photography was still rare, the death of a family member was often the first time a family considered taking a portrait. They did this to commemorate the dead, and to have an image of the deceased — probably their only one. He was so close to its detonation point that he essentially vaporized. This sort of shadow is also known as a "death shadow." This one always gets me. This is a capture from a long distance video camera pointed at the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco as a fellow named Gene Sprague commits suicide by falling backward into the Bay. The Golden Gate Bridge is a monument to engineering and art, and has long been a “Must See” sight for any tourist in San Francisco. Any day when you go there you can meet people from all over the world who have come to admire the Bridge, as well as the views you can get from there on a good weather day. It’s so identifiable as San Francisco that it’s included in nearly every movie that takes place in that city that I can think of, including Dark Passage, Vertigo, Dirty Harry, A View To A Kill, Star Trek IV, Zodiac and Inside Out. The 1.7 mile long suspension bridge is like a red, steel heart of the city with cars and people pumping through it every day. But the Bridge is also a symbol of death. It’s a cenotaph to the more than 1,600 people who are known to have committed suicide from it since it opened in 1937. It’s conceivable that more people have jumped unseen in the night or during deep fogs and their bodies washed out to the Pacific. Gene Sprague’s suicide was captured by a film crew that was working on a documentary entitled The Bridge that was released in 2006. The film shows several people jumping to their deaths, including Gene Sprague, and includes interviews with their families and friends. The film crew did try to intervene when they caught someone on camera they felt might jump, and they actually worked with local authorities to prevent six jumps, but they captured more suicides, which are in the final cut. Gene was seen walking up one side of the bridge and then returning on the other side, taking up over an hour and a half of time. His movements didn’t betray his purpose to them, and the filmmakers said they followed him as he just looked like an interesting guy. When I look at this image I wonder how alone, pained and hopeless he may have felt, and yet also at how brave he was to have been able to take that leap. Physically, I can feel my feet also get a little cold each time I see that image of Gene falling backward to his death, knowing the carnage of the impact that comes after that frozen moment. I wonder if he would have been dissuaded from falling off the Bridge if he’d known he was being filmed for a documentary and that his suicide would be immortalized on film and could be easily found on the internet? I’m also curious if he regretted his decision during the four to five second drop to the waters of the Bay. Time yourself to five seconds and see how many thoughts you can have even in banal moment of your life. We know that other people who have jumped off the Golden Gate did regret their decision. In September of 2000, 19-year-old Kevin Hines jumped from the Bridge and immediately thought, “What the hell did I just do? I don’t want to die[1].” He was headed to the water head first, but was able to reposition his body to allow for his legs to take the brunt of the shock of the impact and to minimize the damage to his head and upper body in the hopes that he would live. While he was badly injured with a broken ankle and a damaged spine, Kevin survived impact. He was lucky, as had his body rotated another centimeter, doctors say he would have crushed his entire spine. After he hit the water he went an estimated 70–80 feet below the surface and used his arms to swim to the air. He struggled to keep his head above the waves and he was swallowing water, but then by further luck he stayed afloat thanks to either a dolphin or sea lion who swam by and propped him up until a Coast Guard crew was able to arrive and pull him from the water. Fifteen years earlier Ken Baldwin, 28, jumped off the Bridge. Ken has said that he “instantly realized that everything in my life that I’d thought was unfixable was totally fixable—except for having just jumped[2].” Having leapt, he experienced a kind of shock therapy where he grasped his situation with a sharper clarity. Luckily for him, while still taking a wallop from the water, he also survived and was rescued by the Coast Guard. Before he jumped, Kevin sat on the bridge crying by himself for 40 minutes. About those 40 minutes, Kevin later recalled that, "I actually had a pact with myself, this is something that many suicidal people do. If one person says 'Are you OK,' 'Is something wrong,' or 'Can I help you?' I was going to tell them everything and beg them to help me”. Eventually a woman did walk up to him, but only to ask him to take a picture of her with his camera. “I was like, ‘Fuck this, nobody cares… So I jumped.[3]” While I’m certain that I would not have asked Kevin to take my picture if I were to see him in that state, I’m not sure if I would have intervened in any other way. My gut reaction would probably be to think that a crying stranger wants to be left alone, and if I were to ask how they are they might tell me to get bent. But, on second thought, considering the location and the history of that bridge (someone jumps about every two weeks) maybe I would have tried to talk to him and try to walk him off that bridge. Was Gene, like Kevin, hoping some stranger would be his own temporary guardian angel and reach out to him with genuine concern as he walked the Bridge for 90 minutes? Did he even give off any signals that he was in a suicidal state, or was he psyching himself up to make the jump? Gene’s story is complete, and what his last thoughts were during that long drop are a missing piece. Below are Ken Baldwin (left) and Kevin Hines (right). Both still suffer from depression at times, but they have sought, and continue to seek, help, and are alive to add to their narratives.  The Bridge continues to stand, and is scheduled, after decades of lobbying, to have a safety net installed in 2023 to prevent further jumps. This might look like an innocuous photo but it hints at a dark, insidious period in American history. This young woman was a radium dial painter. In the early 20th century, radium was used by manufacturing companies to create a glow-in-the-dark paint. Young women, many of them teenagers and in their 20s, were hired by the thousands to paint the tiny numbers with radium so they would glow in the dark. In order to get the most precise lines, the women were instructed to utilize a practice known as lip-pointing. The women would place the radium-covered brushes between their lips before painting the strokes. This would be repeated again and again to ensure the brush tip was always pointed. The women had no idea that the element they were using was dangerous. On the contrary, they were told that it was good for them. Radium had been shown to shrink tumours in some patients, so the prevailing public opinion was that the element was a wonder drug. It didn’t take long until some of the women began suffering horrific effects from radium poisoning. The element targeted the bones, so their teeth would begin to rot inside of their jaws, and the girls’ skeletons were disintegrating inside of them. There are reports of women having parts of their jawbones fall out into their mouths, and stories of dentists who, with the slightest pressure, were able to fully remove a patient’s jawbone. Some women had disfiguring tumours grow on their faces. The pain that these girls suffered is hard to imagine. To make it all the worse, the companies responsible misled the women; when reports came out regarding the harmful effects of radium, the companies went to great lengths to try to discredit the scientists, the characters of the women affected, and to hide medical reports that contradicted their narrative. When I see photos of the dial painters and think of the pain that so many of them suffered, it just makes me so sad. It is awful to think of the human suffering caused as a result of ignorance and willful neglect. It is hard to know the exact number of women who died as a direct result of radium poisoning. There are 112 confirmed deaths but the actual number who died as a result of their exposure is thought to be far higher.    If you would like to learn more about this chapter in history, I would recommend Kate Moore’s book The Radium Girls.
